review_title: Best Everday Carry Keychain, Pocket Flashlight Ever!
reviews:
This has got to be one of if not the best EDC pocket or Keychain flashlight ever made. I have spent probably 6 hours researching every EDC keychain, pocket flashlight on the market. I looked at Fenix, Thrunite, Surefire, MecArmy, Streamlight, Jetbeam, Klarus, Torchlab, Eagletac, and last but certainly not last Nitecore. Sure you can spend $100, $200, even $300 for a comparable if not better small EDC flashlight but dollar for dollar the size, performance, and cost of the nitecore tip is hard to beat.

When I first got the light I was very concerned that the 360 lumens would in fact be nowhere near as bright as advertised. After playing with it I thought I might be right. It was bright but after comparing it to a 100 lumen streamlight it seemed only a little brighter.

However after reading the manual I found there is a turbo mode that is activated by pressing and holding the mode button. It was more than twice as bright as the high mode so I do believe it is very close to 360 lumens.

The modes in lumens are: 360 turbo, 150 high, 35 mid, 1 low. The runtime is 30 min turbo, 1 hr 35 min high, 6 hr 30 min mid, 46 hr low. The runtime for each mode is very good for such a small, bright Keychain sized light. The beam distance according to the manual is 74 meters. The beam is more of a flood with a large Hotspot in the center.

The nitecore tip is much smaller than the picture leads it to be. It is small enough to fit on a Keychain but isn't nearly as small as those old button cell photon Keychain lights. It feels solid and well built and the buttons have an excellent audible click to them and work well. I like the two button system. It works well and provides easy ways to cycle through the modes and features.

The light is easy to charge using the provided mini USB cord or you can use your cell phone charger so you don't have to worry about keeping up with a special charger or cord just to charge the light. It charges fast. From a complete drain to fully charged the manual says it takes about 2 hrs. There is a small light under the buttons that will light up red when charging and will turn green when fully charged.

Every problem with the previous 2016 tip has been fixed with this version. They have added a clip that if turned around can protect the buttons from being pressed. If you don't want to use the clip to cover the buttons the light has a feature that will turn off the light after 30 sec. This can be turned off but I don't mind it so far.

All in all I think anyone in the market for a small Keychain sized EDC flashlight will be very happy with this light. It's small, bright, affordable, and easy to use. Everything a good everyday carry light should be. You will be hard pressed to find a brighter, smaller light on the market. Even the much heavier and larger Surefire titan plus that's 3x more expensive ($90) is only 300 lumens. 360 lumens in this size is almost unheard-of.

review_title: Always ready to light your way
reviews:

The only issues that I’ve experienced with my Tip is on occasion the battery level red led will flash on a slow one flash per 5 second + - intervals for no reason. If I remember correctly the gang at Nitecore recommended plugging the light in for charging and it resets the the light to stop flashing.
The other issue was with the silicone rubber switch covers partially coming out of the housing when removing flashlight from my front pocket. It was easy to reinstall the cover using a thin rounded edge to push the cover back into the housing. Now I make sure I only insert a key in my pocket and use the flashlight to pull the keys from my pocket. The charging cord that is provided by this reseller isn’t from Nitecore and is made from what seems like thicker wire insulation as well as thicker plastic covered USB connectors. This thicker insulation make the cable somewhat less pliable but, isn’t an issue for me.
I usually buy Surefire products but, I didn’t like the plastic housing on their keychain flashlight that kinda looks like the Tip and I didn’t like the price on the Titan model.
Overall a versatile easy to use sturdy keychain flashlight that won’t add a lot of weight to your keychain. Don’t overload your ignition lock with a heavy keychain!

review_title: Outstanding performance as a flashlight, but I knocked off points for the paint job (see photo)
reviews:
This flashlight deserves a full review with video and everything, but for now I will say that it is a perfect addition to your EDC. Takes up about as much space as a BIC lighter, puts out an insane amount of light (I don't know the specs off the top of my head but I'm sure it's on the product page; I will say it is enough to blind someone, so be careful and don't point it at anyone).

Very simple to use. I lost the instructions a while ago but the functionality is easy to remember. Hold both buttons to toggle auto-off, hold down the front for turbo, and click to cycle. I use this daily as it is easier to use and hold than my phone, and puts out both more light and a more controllable light. Low is enough to read something in a dark room (as a bartender, I'll often use this to help a customer who needs to sign their check), and as I mentioned before, the high and turbo will blind someone. It will light up a pitch black driveway; I've used this to check outside my window at night. Bear in mind there is obviously no throw on this.

Overall, I can't stop singing praises of this thing's performance. According to Amazon, I've had this for a year (as of this review) and it has not failed. Battery life is great too, although I don't keep this on for hours at a time (the most was about 45 minutes).

The big negative that cost this product 2 stars: the paint job. I paid extra for the stainless steel "tropical" color, and within a few months it started flaking off. FLAKING. The paint job is similar to what you will find on die cast hot wheel cars (I believe it's acrylic?), so if you've ever seen a toy car flaking paint, that's basically what happened within a month of this purchase. I didn't expose it to any harsh chemicals, it was either in my pocket or in my hand. Nitecore, what happened? It broke my heart to take off two stars but come on, a vinyl skin would have probably lasted longer than whatever paint you used that chipped off and scratched my hands.

Terrible paint job aside, I would still recommend this to anyone who needs to carry a good light and doesn't want a full tube taking up space in their pocket. In fact, I recommend this to new employees at my bar daily, as we often need to perform maintenance in dark areas.

P.S.: use the auto-off if you leave this in your pocket, the body of this thing will get very hot in a concentrated area (not the bulb, but the LED electronic parts inside) and could burn you through your pocket.
